speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: We'll hear argument now in number 04-480, MGM Studios versus Grokster, Limited. Mr. Verrilli.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I just interrupt for the one -- you said "the only significant use." There's a footnote in the red brief that says the figure is some 2.6 billion legitimate uses.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Is that correct, or incorrect?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Now, was there a finding of 90 percent?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: It goes to the - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- accuracy of your statement that there is no other significant legitimate use.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But there could be. There could be, both with respect to material in the public domain and with respect to people who authorize the transmission.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: BUt, your argument, I take it, would be the same if the proportions were reversed. Your argument with respect to -- your current argument with respect to infringing use would be the same if only 10 percent -- if it were assumed that only 10 percent of the use were illegitimate and infringing. Is that correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: That's right. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Is that the same as active inducement - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- as that term - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- is used?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: If we should think that the Respondents are not liable for the type of contributory infringement dealt with in Sony, could this Court reach the question of active inducement on this record?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: I know you do, but - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- I just said - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- could you - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- assume, for a moment, that 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 we didn't; could we, nonetheless, address the active inducement - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: It's not clear -- it's not clear to me from your brief, focusing on the contributory aspect of it, not -- and not the inducement part of it - - it's not clear to me from your brief what your test is. What do we tell the trier of fact, that if there is a substantial part of the use which is noninfringement, if there's any part?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Leaving aside the inducement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, then we just throw this to the birds on the trier of fact in every case - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, how do we know - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You're not saying -- now you're using different tests. Your test is "substantial." All right, on your test, are we sure, if you were the counsel to Mr. Carlson, that you recommend going ahead with the Xerox machine? Are you sure, if you were the counsel to the creator of the VCR, that you could recommend, given the use, copying movies, that we should ever have a VCR? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 -- Are you sure that you could recommend to the iPod inventor that he could go ahead and have an iPod, or, for that matter, Gutenberg, the press? I mean, you see the problem.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What's the answer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Because in each case -- for all I know, the monks had a fit when Gutenberg made his press [Laughter.]

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- but the problem, of course, is that it could well be, in each of those instances, that there will be vast numbers of infringing uses that are foreseeable.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: How do you -- how do you know, going in, Mr. Verrilli? I mean, I'm about to start the business. How much time do you give me to bring up the lawful use to the level where it will outweigh the unlawful use? I have to know, going in.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And it's one thing to sit back and, you know, calculate with this ongoing business, it's 90 percent/10 percent. But I'm a new inventor, and I'm - - you know - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- I'm going to get sued right away. I know I'm going to get sued right away, before I have a chance to build up a business. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, I don't quite understand the -- I take it, inventors are profit-motive-driven, and if they know that something they're working on is going to have copyright experience, you -- have got copyright problems, you can't just say, "Oh, well, the inventor's going to invent anyway."

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Or did I misunderstand your - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But the inventor of Xerox does that. I mean, he puts out the machine. He knows some - - he knows a lot of people are going to use it to Xerox 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 books.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, let's go - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- let's go from Xerox back to your iPod. How is that clear in the iPod case? I may not understand what people are doing out there, but it's certainly not clear to me. I know perfectly well I could go out and buy a CD and put it on my iPod, but I also know perfectly well that if I can get the music on the iPod without buying the CD, that's what I'm going to do. And I think it's reasonable to suppose that everybody else would guess that. So why, in the iPod, do you not have this Damoclean sword?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, there's never evidence at the time the guy is sitting in the garage figuring out 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 whether to invent the iPod or not. I mean, that's - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- the concern.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay, but you're - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, but you're - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- you're not answering - - you're not answering the question. The question is, How do we know in advance, on your test, anything that would give the inventor, or, more exactly, the developer, the confidence to go ahead? As was said a minute ago, he knows he's going to be sued immediately. There isn't a product performance out there, as there is in this case. So, on your substantiality theory, why isn't it a foregone conclusion in the iPod that the iPod loser -- or developer is going to lose his shirt?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's your second argument, I think. I thought you were going to just stick with the - - with the first one. I mean, that's an inducement argument.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yes, that's inducement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But it is the case under the test you're submitting to us.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, are you dealing with active inducement as just a theoretical add-on, or is that a satisfactory way to resolve this case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: I don't understand - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- your pitch.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But you couldn't get summary judgment. Your reply brief said, "This case is so clear that we should get summary judgment." If inducement is the theory -- you have just said, you have to show intent

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- so you could not - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- you'd have to go to trial.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Sony itself had a trial - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- a full trial.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: Very well, Mr. Verrilli. Mr. Clement, we'll hear from you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, what do you think Sony allowed? It talked about -- if it's, what, capable of substantial noninfringing use, it's okay?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And what -- and your test is whether there's a substantial use that's lawful?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: Mr. Clement, where did the 90 percent figure come from? I know we have to accept it because it's summary judgment, but where did it come from?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I thought it was just limited to music.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I know, but I thought the study was about music.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, I thought -- I mean, you know, we've had 90 briefs in this, and some briefs tear it apart, and others support it, but we also have briefs from the ACLU saying you could put whole libraries within this system.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The question I wanted to ask you is, given that concern, that there are, conceptually anyway, really excellent uses of this thing, does deliberate -- what is the word?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes. Because what you are worried about, it seemed to me that the actual inducement would take care of. And if you sent it back and said, "Let's have a trial on actual inducement." If this really is the extreme case you're talking about, why wouldn't the Petitioners here be bound to win that trial?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, you got interrupted a bit. Tell us, in the simplest way you can, what test you think Sony stands for and how the Ninth got it wrong, if you believe it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Suppose the owner of the instrumentality, the program, thinks that there's going to be a vast area of lawful use, and he knows that there's going to be some abuse at the -- in the short term, but he does everything he can to discourage that. He says, "This is a two -- P2P is going to revolutionize the way we talk to each other, there's things in the public domain. Please don't use this for copyright." But he knows that there's going to be some infringement, let's say that it'll be 50 percent of the use, in the short term. Can he use the program?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Yes, that he can - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- use the program.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: If there's more, they could bring it out at trial, could they not? The difference between your position and Mr. Verrilli, I take it, is that you think there should be not summary judgment for the Petitioners, but a trial.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The inducement -- the inducement point doesn't get you very far. Presumably a successor to Grokster, or whatever this outfit is called, could simply come in and not induce anybody but say, you know, "We're setting up the same system," know very well what people are going to use it for, but not induce them. And that would presumably be okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Which is why you need - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- the Sony - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Will you give a company ten 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 years to establish that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, what I worry about is the suit that just comes right out of the box, as soon as the company starts up. Will you give the company a couple of years to show that it's developing a commercial use?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Mr. Clement, in one way this presents an easy case for answering Justice Scalia's question, but what about a case in which there isn't the Napster example to start with? Should there be some kind of a flexible rightness doctrine in response to suits, as Justice Scalia put it, against the inventor or developer right out of the box?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Congress of laches.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Congress of laches.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: How would you express the - - how would you express that, that substantive standard that anticipates, just as you suggested we do?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Clement.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: Mr. Taranto, we'll hear from you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Yes, but active inducement is a doctrine that's been employed to curb the intentional encouragement of noninfringing uses, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But they are inherent. They are inherent. I mean, the point is that those past acts are what have developed your client's current clientele.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But I don't - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- understand how you can separate the past from the present in that fashion. One, I suppose, could say, "Well, I'm going to make inducing remarks Monday through Thursday, and I'm going to stop, Thursday night." The sales of the product on Friday are still going to be sales which are the result of the inducing remarks Monday through Wednesday. And you're asking, in effect -- you're asking us -- to ignore Monday through Thursday.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Then why was current -- why was inducement, as a current theory of recovery, even the subject of summary judgment? It seems to me that to make it a summary judgment is implausible to a nonworldly degree.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: I mean, I thought you were saying that, so far as the inducement theory of recovery is concerned - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- the only summary judgment that was granted was with respect to current acts of inducement, the way the company is acting now, not the way the company was acting last year. And my question is - - if that is correct, then I don't see how summary judgment could even intelligibly have been considered. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, I don't want to get us too far off the track on this question, but it just seems to me that what you've done before bears on what you know, or have reason to know, on an ongoing basis.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, then why don't you tell us what's wrong with the Government's test and with the 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 Petitioner's test, the substantial-use part of it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: That, Mr. Taranto, is something I find very puzzling. There is a statement - - one could take it as clear -- "capable of substantial noninfringing use." That would be very clear, I agree. But Sony goes on for 13 more pages. If the standard were all that clear, it would have stopped there. And usually when you're interpreting a document, one rule is, you read on, and if you read on, you find we need not give precise content to the question of how much use is commercially significant. That doesn't sound very clear to me. Or if you then read back, as a careful reader would, then you find this statement that the primary use of the Sony machine for most owners was time-shifting, a use that the Court found either authorized or fair, and, hence, noninfringing. So I don't think you can take from what is a rather long opinion, and isolate one sentence, and say, "Aha, we have a clear rule."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Verrilli, I hope you won't waste a lot of your time on this point. This Court is certainly not going to decide this case on the basis of stare decisis, you know, whatever else is true.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What is -- what is the answer to Justice Kennedy's question? I took it, whether -- for the last 21 years, industry throughout America has taken the standard as being approximately whether it is capable of substantial -- commercially significant substantial noninfringing uses.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I -- and the country seems to have survived that standard. There is innovation. There are problems in the music industry, but it thrives, and so forth. So there is an argument for just following it, because it's what it is. But suppose it's totally open. Why should that be the right test, instead of some other test, like substantial use, et cetera?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That, I think, was the question, and I'm very interested in your answer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- but what you have -- what you want to do is to say that unlawfully expropriated property can be used by the owner of the instrumentality as part of the startup capital for his product.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And I -- just from an economic standpoint and a legal standpoint, that sounds wrong to me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So you think that - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- unlawfully expropriated property can be a legitimate part of the startup capital.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Then perhaps there should be a trial so it would all come out.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, they weren't concentrating on the damage to them, they were concentrating on the facilitation of copying that was provided. And you don't question that this service does facilitate copying.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, you said -- I think you were saying -- this is something for Congress to solve; it's not for the Court. But the Court is now faced with two apparently conflicting decisions: Aimster, in the Seventh Circuit, the Ninth Circuit decision. And if you're just looking at this in the abstract, you might say, "Well, it's -- isn't it odd that Napster goes one way in the Ninth Circuit, and this case goes another way?"

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Why isn't this a classic willful-ignorance case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Sure, but I thought willful ignorance was basically a certainty of what was going on without empirically verifying it, so as to, sort of, maintain the guise of one's hands over one's eyes. And it seems to me, if that's what it is, that's what we've got.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes, I think it would also include disabling yourself from looking at it. And so, I think it's an important part of your case, that you didn't adopt this new system of decentralizing the file so that it's in the computers, out there, solely in order to get around Napster.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, wait. In respect to that -- I mean, is it open? If you win on the question of the standard, is it open, or would we have to remand it for them to argue, in light of the history, in light of what they do now, they, your client, with knowledge of infringement, actively encouraged users to infringe copyright using their -- using the Grokster technology, and, indeed, knowingly would include willful blindness?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Because -- as I had gotten that from one of these amicus briefs, you know, that's their standard -- they say a willful -- of willful, deliberate inducement. And that, it seems to me, important that they be able to argue that. Now, can they argue it, in your opinion, if we do nothing but affirm the Ninth Circuit? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mr. Taranto - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- can I ask -- I'm still a little puzzled about the posture of the case. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Because I read the District Court opinion. I think he said -- the judge said that both parties agreed that there were no disputed issues of fact that would preclude the entry of summary judgment in either way, no disputed issues relative to whether to grant relief. And I -- it's on page 24a of the cert petition. And I understand you to be saying that leaving everything alone, affirming would allow the case to go forward with your adversaries seeking damages on an active-inducement theory. Am I correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But it says, "Both parties believe there are no disputed issues of fact material to Defendant's liability."

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So then your answer to my question is that, yes, if we affirm, as a possibility, they could continue to seek damages on an active- inducement theory. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And then one other - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- question I had. Does the record contain their proposed form of injunction that they requested?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Taranto, before you go back to that, I wanted to be clear on what you were saying would be left over for trial.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Because, as I read your briefing, it was, "Well, they can argue about some bad things that Grokster was doing in the past, but this decision says: henceforth, what we're doing is okay. The 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 case zeroed in on now and the future, and the only thing that was left open was something that is over and gone could get damages for it." But I thought that this judgment gave you an okay, a green light, from now on.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Then what is the point of the current summary judgment?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So you're saying the summary judgment simply, in effect, says, "They're not doing anything wrong now, but we have left open the question, not merely of what they have done wrong in the past, but whether what they did wrong in the past can carry forward into the future"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: That's bizarre.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So you're saying -- what it really says is, "There's nothing to enjoin, but there may very well be something to recover for," - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- "even as to future activity."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Because, I gather, that some artists don't make money from the records, but make money from the popularity that draws fans to their concerts.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So they're willing to give away the records for free.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: Mr. Taranto?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: In your motion for summary judgment, did you ask that the Plaintiff's claim be dismissed?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: Were there other claims? You said "on their claim." Were -- did they make other claims?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Where does one find that?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: (Inaudible)

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But the motion itself is not there to take it through the opinion of the Court?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: The text on - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: -- the text, on pages 23a and 24a, gives the impression that the District Court is disposing of the entire case.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Taranto. Mr. Verrilli, you have four minutes remaining.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: Thank you - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: -- Mr. Verrilli. Thank you.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: The case is submitted. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400
